Facteur de vitesse : 3
Type de compétence : Katana / Wakizashi
Type : Arme à 1 main

Poids : 3

Nécessite : 
- Force : 5
SW1H47
Wakizashi +1
The wakizashi, or companion sword, is extremely important to samurai. It is worn at all times, even indoors, and is near the samurai when he sleeps at night. As finely made as the katana, the wakizashi is a shorter sword with a length between 12 and 24 inches, and is a dangerous weapon in the hands of a skilled user. Wu Jen masters have concealed within this wakizashi great power, unleashed only when the wielder is in the thick of battle. How or why this wakizashi made it to Faerûn is unknown, but if the samurai who owned it still lives, he will certainly be looking for it.

STATISTICS:

THAC0: +1
Damage: 1d8+1 (slashing)
Speed Factor: 3
Proficiency Type: Katana / Wakizashi
Type: One-handed
Requires:
 5 Strength

Weight: 3
The wakizashi, or companion sword, is extremely important to samurai. It is worn at all times, even indoors, and is near the samurai when he sleeps at night. As finely made as the katana, the wakizashi is a shorter sword with a length between 12 and 24 inches, and is a dangerous weapon in the hands of a skilled user. Wu Jen masters have concealed within this wakizashi great power, unleashed only when the wielder is in the thick of battle. How or why this wakizashi made it to Faerûn is unknown, but if the samurai who owned it still lives, he will certainly be looking for it.

PARAMÈTRES : 

Capacités d'équipement : 
- TAC0 de la main secondaire : +1

Enchantement : +1
TAC0 : +1
Dégâts : 1d8 +1
Type de dégâts : Tranchant
Facteur de vitesse : 3
Type de compétence : Katana / Wakizashi
Type : Arme à 1 main

Poids : 3

Nécessite : 
- Force : 5
SW1H48
Ninjato
The sword of the ninja, the ninjato, is of lower quality than other Kara-Tur blades such as the katana. The ninjato is short with a straight blade, making it ideal for the subterfuge of the ninja. The ninjato is also more suited to fighting in closed places, sometimes giving the ninja an advantage over those using longer blades such as the samurai used.

STATISTICS:

Damage: 1d6 (piercing)
Speed Factor: 2
Proficiency Type: Short Sword / Ninjato
Type: One-handed
Requires:
 6 Strength

Weight: 3
The sword of the ninja, the ninjato, is of lower quality than other Kara-Tur blades such as the katana. The ninjato is short with a straight blade, making it ideal for the subterfuge of the ninja. The ninjato is also more suited to fighting in closed places, sometimes giving the ninja an advantage over those using longer blades such as the samurai used.

SW1H49
Ninjato +1
The sword of the ninja, the ninjato, is of lower quality than other Kara-Tur blades such as the katana. The ninjato is short with a straight blade, making it ideal for the subterfuge of the ninja. The ninjato is also more suited to fighting in closed places, sometimes giving the ninja an advantage over those using longer blades such as the samurai used. This particular ninjato has been enhanced magically to complement the skill of the wielder.

SW1H50
Shazzellim +1
This scimitar is of rather poor quality, but beneath its surface lies great power and evil. Created for the sole purpose of slaying Harpers, Shazzellim is more than capable of that task. With one strike of the blade, a bard must make a save vs. death or die. Crafted by a Red Wizard of Thay, the sword also has the ability to vocalize, which is why it was often given to fighter-mages in the service of the Wizards. Needless to say, possession of this sword would not be looked upon very highly by Harpers.

STATISTICS:

Equipped abilities:
– Spell: Vocalize

Combat abilities:
– Song Slayer: bards struck die (save vs. Death at -2 negates)

THAC0: +1
Damage: 1d8+1 (slashing)
Speed Factor: 5
Proficiency Type: Scimitar
Type: One-handed
Requires:
 8 Strength

Weight: 4
This scimitar is of rather poor quality, but beneath its surface lies great power and evil. Created for the sole purpose of slaying Harpers, Shazzellim is more than capable of that task. With one strike of the blade, a bard must make a save vs. death or die. Crafted by a Red Wizard of Thay, the sword also has the ability to vocalize, which is why it was often given to fighter-mages in the service of the Wizards. Needless to say, possession of this sword would not be looked upon very highly by Harpers.

PARAMÈTRES : 

Capacités d'équipement : 
- Multiplicateur d'attaque sournoise : -1
- Immunité au silence

Capacités de combat : 
- Tue instantanément les bardes (jet de sauvegarde à -2 contre la paralysie, la mort et les poisons pour éviter)

Enchantement : +1
TAC0 : +1
Dégâts : 1d8 +1
Type de dégâts : Tranchant
Facteur de vitesse : 5
Type de compétence : Scimitar
Type : Arme à 1 main

Poids : 4

Nécessite : 
- Force : 8
SW1H51
Celestial Fury +3
Many years ago, fierce tempests and fires ignited by lightning ravished the province administered by daimyo Hoshi Katahiroi. The daimyo's advisers, all respected shukenjas, soon divined that Nature was not to blame, but a powerful dragon of an unknown order. Some of the wise men suggested that the creature was an abomination; others believed that it was born of Primal Chaos before Kara-Tur was formed. All the advisers agreed to name it Celestial Fury.

Yet daimyo Hoshi did not want to categorize the scourge of his province; he wanted to destroy it. He commissioned the famed Chigatta (a reclusive artisan, master of mystic arts), to construct a weapon that might sunder the dragon's spirit as well as cleave its scaled body. Chigatta's labors resulted in the finest katana imaginable, dubbed Celestial Fury after the beast it was fashioned to destroy, and enchanted with the power of flight.

With this weapon, Hoshi sought his province's bane among the storm clouds. Shouts and roars resounded through the heavens for days, and forked fire lit up the nights. At long last, Hoshi destroyed the dragon's body and trapped its spirit within his sword, merging the two Celestial Furies and impressing order over chaos. To finalize his victory, Hoshi had Chigatta fashion a scabbard from the dragon's hide and embed its magic pearl in the hilt.

Yet the dragon had its revenge. Hoshi was skilled in battle but weak of will. Celestial Fury's spirit took control of Hoshi, forcing him to slay Chigatta and then slay himself. The katana subsequently disappeared (most likely, Hoshi's grieving family discarded the traitorous weapon) and has perhaps changed many hands in the years since.

STATISTICS:

Special abilities:
– Batto (three times per day): thunder and lightning explode from Celestial Fury, blinding and deafening opponents within 10 ft. for 5 rounds (save vs. Breath at -2 negates)
– Lightning Bolt (once per day)

Combat abilities:
– Booming Thunder: target and opponents within 5 ft. are stunned for 1 round (save vs. Breath negates)
– Electrocution: 15% chance of dealing 3d6 electrical damage

THAC0: +3
Damage: 1d10+3 (slashing)
Speed Factor: 5
Proficiency Type: Katana / Wakizashi
Type: One-handed
Requires:
 6 Strength

Weight: 5
Many years ago, fierce tempests and fires ignited by lightning ravished the province administered by daimyo Hoshi Katahiroi. The daimyo's advisers, all respected shukenjas, soon divined that Nature was not to blame, but a powerful dragon of an unknown order. Some of the wise men suggested that the creature was an abomination; others believed that it was born of Primal Chaos before Kara-Tur was formed. All the advisers agreed to name it Celestial Fury.

Yet daimyo Hoshi did not want to categorize the scourge of his province; he wanted to destroy it. He commissioned the famed Chigatta (a reclusive artisan, master of mystic arts), to construct a weapon that might sunder the dragon's spirit as well as cleave its scaled body. Chigatta's labors resulted in the finest katana imaginable, dubbed Celestial Fury after the beast it was fashioned to destroy, and enchanted with the power of flight.

With this weapon, Hoshi sought his province's bane among the storm clouds. Shouts and roars resounded through the heavens for days, and forked fire lit up the nights. At long last, Hoshi destroyed the dragon's body and trapped its spirit within his sword, merging the two Celestial Furies and impressing order over chaos. To finalize his victory, Hoshi had Chigatta fashion a scabbard from the dragon's hide and embed its magic pearl in the hilt.

Yet the dragon had its revenge. Hoshi was skilled in battle but weak of will. Celestial Fury's spirit took control of Hoshi, forcing him to slay Chigatta and then slay himself. The katana subsequently disappeared (most likely, Hoshi's grieving family discarded the traitorous weapon) and has perhaps changed many hands in the years since.

PARAMÈTRES : 

Capacités d'équipement : 
- TAC0 de la main secondaire : -1
- Multiplicateur d'attaque sournoise : -1

Capacités de charge : 
- Batto (3 fois par jour)
- Lightning Bolt (1 fois par jour)

Capacités de combat : 
- Etourdit les adversaires dans un rayon d'1,50 mètre pendant 1 round (jet de sauvegarde contre les souffles pour éviter)
- 15 % de chance d'infliger 3d6 points de dégâts d'électricité à la cible

Enchantement : +3
TAC0 : +3
Dégâts : 1d10 +3
Type de dégâts : Tranchant
Facteur de vitesse : 5
Type de compétence : Katana / Wakizashi
Type : Arme à 1 main

Poids : 5

Nécessite : 
- Force : 6
SW1H52
Water's Edge +3
Due to their religious responsibilities, minions of Umberlee, are supposed to avoid personal entanglements with those who work the sea. Of course, even among those who follow dark gods, the pursuit of pleasure and emotional gratification often cause them to stray from their commandments. One priestess who strayed in such a fashion was Kalana Fisher. In 1357, she began a romance with the pirate captain Balhoderie. Though both were extremely flawed people with outrageous personalities and a complete lack of faithfulness, they had a strange mutual affection for each other. But while Balhoderie's great flaw was his mean temper, Kalana's was in holding grudges.

In 1366, Kalana tracked down the murderer of Balhoderie, a Talosian pirate captain named Madion. She planted information in Madion's spy network and anonymously offered him a tantalizing prize: three high-value merchant ships leaving the port of Baldur's Gate with few defenses. Low on money, Madion took the bait. He was slaughtered by the numerous guards that poured from the ships' holds.

As it had turned out, the merchant captain was a superstitious sort and had gone to the temple of Umberlee in Baldur's Gate for a divination. Without hesitation, the priestess Kalana had foretold a horrible attack outside the port. Not only did Kalana get her revenge, but the captain became a lifelong donator to the church of the Bitch Queen.

Nobody knows if Water's Edge, the blade Kalane had crafted for Balhoderie, was somehow retreived by the priestess herself or got lost in the ocean.

STATISTICS:

Combat abilities:
– Armor Piercing: +3 to THAC0

THAC0: +3
Damage: 1d8+3 (slashing)
Speed Factor: 5
Proficiency Type: Scimitar
Type: One-handed
Requires:
 8 Strength

Weight: 4
Due to their religious responsibilities, minions of Umberlee, are supposed to avoid personal entanglements with those who work the sea. Of course, even among those who follow dark gods, the pursuit of pleasure and emotional gratification often cause them to stray from their commandments. One priestess who strayed in such a fashion was Kalana Fisher. In 1357, she began a romance with the pirate captain Balhoderie. Though both were extremely flawed people with outrageous personalities and a complete lack of faithfulness, they had a strange mutual affection for each other. But while Balhoderie's great flaw was his mean temper, Kalana's was in holding grudges.

In 1366, Kalana tracked down the murderer of Balhoderie, a Talosian pirate captain named Madion. She planted information in Madion's spy network and anonymously offered him a tantalizing prize: three high-value merchant ships leaving the port of Baldur's Gate with few defenses. Low on money, Madion took the bait. He was slaughtered by the numerous guards that poured from the ships' holds.

As it had turned out, the merchant captain was a superstitious sort and had gone to the temple of Umberlee in Baldur's Gate for a divination. Without hesitation, the priestess Kalana had foretold a horrible attack outside the port. SW1H53
Sword of Flame +1
Desert Wind
If rumors of Calimshite ancestry are true, then this type of scimitar is likely the product of the genies that founded the city long ago. All of the raging heat of the desert seems to be captured within the blade of the sword. Tales of enemies surrendering after suffering a mere scratch only seem true after one has tasted the blistering pain this flaming sword causes a wound.

STATISTICS:

Combat abilities:
– Fiery: target suffers 1d4 fire damage
– Immolation: 15% chance of dealing 3d6 fire damage

THAC0: +1
Damage: 1d8+1 (slashing)
Speed Factor: 5
Proficiency Type: Scimitar
Type: One-handed
Requires:
 8 Strength

Weight: 4

SW1H54
The Equalizer +4
The age of this sword is such that its true origin has been lost to time, but markings hint that it was possibly forged by those in the service of Helm. Also called the "Sword of Neutrality," it seems designed to seek and terminate extremism, to shift the universe closer to harmonious equilibrium. The further the orientation of a target from true balance, the more potent the damage they suffer.

The Equalizer was last rumored to have been wielded by the elven hero Alaine Greenleaf, who was lost during a voyage to the Underdark, though the blade's pommel gem was stolen by an escaped slave who returned to the surface world.

STATISTICS:

Equipped abilities:
– Protects Against: Charm, Confusion, and Domination

Combat abilities:
– Equalizer: deals damage depending on target's alignment:
 +0 vs. True Neutral
 +2 vs. Lawful/Chaotic Neutral
 +4 vs. Neutral Good/Evil
 +6 vs. Lawful/Chaotic Good/Evil

THAC0: +4
Damage: 1d8+4 (slashing)
Speed Factor: 5
Proficiency Type: Long Sword
Type: One-handed
Requires:
 6 Strength

Weight: 4
The age of this sword is such that its true origin has been lost to time, but markings hint that it was possibly forged by those in the service of Helm. Also called the "Sword of Neutrality," it seems designed to seek and terminate extremism, to shift the universe closer to harmonious equilibrium. The further the orientation of a target from true balance, the more potent the damage they suffer.

The Equalizer was last rumored to have been wielded by the elven hero Alaine Greenleaf, who was lost during a voyage to the Underdark, though the blade's pommel gem was stolen by an escaped slave who returned to the surface world.

PARAMÈTRES : 

Capacités d'équipement : 
- Inflige 6 points de dégâts contre les créatures loyales bonnes
- Inflige 6 points de dégâts contre les créatures loyales mauvaises
- Inflige 6 points de dégâts contre les créatures chaotiques bonnes
- Inflige 6 points de dégâts contre les créatures chaotiques mauvaises
- Inflige 4 points de dégâts contre les créatures neutres mauvaises
- Inflige 4 points de dégâts contre les créatures neutres bonnes
- Inflige 2 points de dégâts contre les créatures loyales neutres
- Inflige 2 points de dégâts contre les créatures chaotiques neutres
- Multiplicateur d'attaque sournoise : -1
- Immunité à la confusion
- Immunité aux charmes

Enchantement : +4
TAC0 : +4
Dégâts : 1d8 +4
Type de dégâts : Tranchant
Facteur de vitesse : 5
Type de compétence : Épée longue
Type : Arme à 1 main

Poids : 4

Nécessite : 
- Force : 6
SW1H55
Katana +2
It is no simple deed to enchant a katana. Unlike conventional weapons, the katana is already a near-perfect fighting sword. Improving it further usually requires a sacrifice; perhaps a dying samurai might beg a Wu Jen to infuse his fighting spirit into his sword. The wielder of an enchanted katana such as this one must respect the customs of Kara-Tur and of the samurai who once carried the blade into battle. Not doing so could drastically change one's luck for the worse.

STATISTICS:

THAC0: +2
Damage: 1d10+2 (slashing)
Speed Factor: 5
Proficiency Type: Katana / Wakizashi
Type: One-handed
Requires:
 6 Strength

Weight: 5
It is no simple deed to enchant a katana. Unlike conventional weapons, the katana is already a near-perfect fighting sword. Improving it further usually requires a sacrifice; perhaps a dying samurai might beg a Wu Jen to infuse his fighting spirit into his sword. The wielder of an enchanted katana such as this one must respect the customs of Kara-Tur and of the samurai who once carried the blade into battle. Not doing so could drastically change one's luck for the worse.

- Multiplicateur d'attaque sournoise : -1

SW1H56
Scimitar
The long, curved, single-edged blade is characteristic of both the sabre and the scimitar, even though their origins lie in different parts of Faerûn. Whereas the sabre was intended mainly for horsemen due to its versatility, the scimitar has a heavier oriental influence. The "shamshir," as it was originally called, is larger, has a greater curve to it, and is tapered to an elongated, sharp point. Thus, it is slightly slower, but tends to be more effective and deadly in combat.

STATISTICS:

Damage: 1d8 (slashing)
Speed Factor: 5
Proficiency Type: Scimitar
Type: One-handed
Requires:
 8 Strength

Weight: 4
The long, curved, single-edged blade is characteristic of both the sabre and the scimitar, even though their origins lie in different parts of Faerûn. Whereas the sabre was intended mainly for horsemen due to its versatility, the scimitar has a heavier oriental influence. The "shamshir," as it was originally called, is larger, has a greater curve to it, and is tapered to an elongated, sharp point. Thus, it is slightly slower, but tends to be more effective and deadly in combat.

PARAMÈTRES : 

Capacités d'équipement : 
- Multiplicateur d'attaque sournoise : -1

Dégâts : 1d8 
Type de dégâts : Tranchant
Facteur de vitesse : 5
Type de compétence : Scimitar
Type : Arme à 1 main

Poids : 4

Nécessite : 
- Force : 8
SW1H57
Dague de jet


Capacités d'équipement : 
- TAC0 de la main secondaire : +1
- Attaque par round : Passe à 2

Capacités de charge : 
- Crée 1 "Scimitar" dans l'inventaire de la cible de manière permanente (1 charge, l'objet est détruit quand la charge est utilisée)

TAC0 : +32767
Dégâts : 1d2 
Type de dégâts : Projectile
Facteur de vitesse : 1
Type de compétence : Dague
Type : Arme à 1 main

Poids : 0

Nécessite : 
- Force : 3
SW1H58
Short Sword of Mask +4
Godsbane Legacy
This blade is highly prized by those who serve the Shadowlord, as well as any who engage in shadowy business.

Godsbane was the sword form assumed by Mask during the Time of Troubles. He would eventually come to be wielded by the then-mortal Cyric, who acquired the sword by murdering a halfling named Sneakabout, who in turn killed the former wielder of the sword.

Cyric named the sword "Godsbane" because while he was a mortal, he used it to slay Bhaal (then Lord of Murder), and after becoming a deity, he used it to kill Leira, Lady of Deception.

The soon-to-become Prince of Lies also used it to kill Kelemvor Lyonsbane while atop Blackstaff Tower, but to spite Cyric for trying to break his will while he was a mortal, Mask as Godsbane hid Kelemvor's soul from him. During a revolt in the City of Strife that marked the end of Cyric's reign as Lord of the Dead, Cyric learned of this and snapped the blade in two. This revealed the sword to be an aspect of Mask, the god of thievery and intrigue. By doing this, Cyric greatly weakened Mask and gained the portfolio of intrigue, along with shadowy characteristics. For this, Mask hates Cyric, and he continuously plots ways to recover his lost portfolio.

Whether this blade is one of the original sword's reproductions, or another of Mask's attempts to seek his revenge is beyond anyone's knowledge.

STATISTICS:

Combat abilities:
– Poisonous: target suffers 1d6 poison damage
– Stealthblade: 15% chance that the wielder becomes invisible for 5 rounds

THAC0: +4
Damage: 1d6+4 (slashing)
Speed Factor: 3
Proficiency Type: Short Sword / Ninjato
Type: One-handed
Requires:
 5 Strength

Weight: 3
Godsbane Legacy
This blade is highly prized by those who serve the Shadowlord, as well as any who engage in shadowy business.

Godsbane was the sword form assumed by Mask during the Time of Troubles. He would eventually come to be wielded by the then-mortal Cyric, who acquired the sword by murdering a halfling named Sneakabout, who in turn killed the former wielder of the sword.

Cyric named the sword "Godsbane" because while he was a mortal, he used it to slay Bhaal (then Lord of Murder), and after becoming a deity, he used it to kill Leira, Lady of Deception.

The soon-to-become Prince of Lies also used it to kill Kelemvor Lyonsbane while atop Blackstaff Tower, but to spite Cyric for trying to break his will while he was a mortal, Mask as Godsbane hid Kelemvor's soul from him. During a revolt in the City of Strife that marked the end of Cyric's reign as Lord of the Dead, Cyric learned of this and snapped the blade in two. This revealed the sword to be an aspect of Mask, the god of thievery and intrigue. By doing this, Cyric greatly weakened Mask and gained the portfolio of intrigue, along with shadowy characteristics. For this, Mask hates Cyric, and he continuously plots ways to recover his lost portfolio.

Whether this blade is one of the original sword's reproductions, or another of Mask's attempts to seek his revenge is beyond anyone's knowledge.

PARAMÈTRES : 

Capacités d'équipement : 
- TAC0 de la main secondaire : +1

Capacités de combat : 
- Inflige 1d6 points de dégâts de poison à la cible
- 15 % de chance de lancer Invisibilité sur le porteur pendant 5 rounds

Enchantement : +4
TAC0 : +4
Dégâts : 1d6 +4
Type de dégâts : Tranchant
Facteur de vitesse : 3
Type de compétence : Short Sword / Ninjato

SW1H59
Short Sword of Mask +5
Godsbane Legacy
This blade is highly prized by those who serve the Shadowlord, as well as any who engage in shadowy business.

Godsbane was the sword form assumed by Mask during the Time of Troubles. He would eventually come to be wielded by the then-mortal Cyric, who acquired the sword by murdering a halfling named Sneakabout, who in turn killed the former wielder of the sword.

Cyric named the sword "Godsbane" because while he was a mortal, he used it to slay Bhaal (then Lord of Murder), and after becoming a deity, he used it to kill Leira, Lady of Deception.

The soon-to-become Prince of Lies also used it to kill Kelemvor Lyonsbane while atop Blackstaff Tower, but to spite Cyric for trying to break his will while he was a mortal, Mask as Godsbane hid Kelemvor's soul from him. During a revolt in the City of Strife that marked the end of Cyric's reign as Lord of the Dead, Cyric learned of this and snapped the blade in two. This revealed the sword to be an aspect of Mask, the god of thievery and intrigue. By doing this, Cyric greatly weakened Mask and gained the portfolio of intrigue, along with shadowy characteristics. For this, Mask hates Cyric, and he continuously plots ways to recover his lost portfolio.

Whether this blade is one of the original sword's reproductions, or another of Mask's attempts to seek his revenge is beyond anyone's knowledge.

Combined with the Heart of the Damned into a single lethal weapon, this deadly blade is now an unmatched tool of assassins and thieves.

STATISTICS:

Combat abilities:
– Poisonous: target suffers 1d8 poison damage
– Paralyzing: 33% chance target is held for 2 rounds (save vs. Paralyzation negates)
– Stealthblade: 25% chance that the wielder becomes invisible for 5 rounds

THAC0: +5
Damage: 1d6+5 (slashing)
Speed Factor: 3
Proficiency Type: Short Sword / Ninjato
Type: One-handed
Requires:
 5 Strength

Weight: 3
Godsbane Legacy
This blade is highly prized by those who serve the Shadowlord, as well as any who engage in shadowy business.

Godsbane was the sword form assumed by Mask during the Time of Troubles. He would eventually come to be wielded by the then-mortal Cyric, who acquired the sword by murdering a halfling named Sneakabout, who in turn killed the former wielder of the sword.

Cyric named the sword "Godsbane" because while he was a mortal, he used it to slay Bhaal (then Lord of Murder), and after becoming a deity, he used it to kill Leira, Lady of Deception.

The soon-to-become Prince of Lies also used it to kill Kelemvor Lyonsbane while atop Blackstaff Tower, but to spite Cyric for trying to break his will while he was a mortal, Mask as Godsbane hid Kelemvor's soul from him. During a revolt in the City of Strife that marked the end of Cyric's reign as Lord of the Dead, Cyric learned of this and snapped the blade in two. This revealed the sword to be an aspect of Mask, the god of thievery and intrigue. By doing this, Cyric greatly weakened Mask and gained the portfolio of intrigue, along with shadowy characteristics. For this, Mask hates Cyric, and he continuously plots ways to recover his lost portfolio.

Whether this blade is one of the original sword's reproductions, or another of Mask's attempts to seek his revenge is beyond anyone's knowledge.

Combined with the Heart of the Damned into a single lethal weapon, this deadly blade is now an unmatched tool of assassins and thieves.

PARAMÈTRES : 

Capacités d'équipement : 
- TAC0 de la main secondaire : +1

Capacités de combat : 
- Inflige 1d8 points de dégâts de poison à la cible
- 33 % de chance de paralyser la cible pendant 2 rounds (jet de sauvegarde contre la paralysie, la mort et les poisons pour éviter)
- 25 % de chance de lancer Invisibilité sur le porteur pendant 5 rounds

Enchantement : +5
TAC0 : +5
Dégâts : 1d6 +5
Type de dégâts : Tranchant
Facteur de vitesse : 3
Type de compétence : Short Sword / Ninjato
Type : Arme à 1 main

Poids : 3

Nécessite : 
- Force : 5
SW1H60
Angurvadal +4
Burning Earth
There was a time before Neverwinter was warm and before the great Anauroch was dry... or so it is said. Few relics remain to prove such an age existed, and fewer still have an identifiable purpose. "Burning Earth" seems straightforward enough—it burns a victim with magical fire, and a cryptic rune seems to suggest that the power comes from the ground itself—but whoever constructed it remains a mystery. It looks a perfectly serviceable weapon, but something in the balance or grip is... wrong. It strains the forearm a touch, and does not fit the hand just right. It shouldn't hurt a warrior's performance, aside from the nagging suspicion that the blade was not made for him... or any other humanoid.

STATISTICS:

Equipped abilities:
– Strength: +2

Combat abilities:
– Fiery: target suffers 1d6 fire damage

THAC0: +4
Damage: 1d8+4 (slashing)
Speed Factor: 5
Proficiency Type: Long Sword
Type: One-handed
Requires:
 6 Strength

Weight: 4
Burning Earth
There was a time before Neverwinter was warm and before the great Anauroch was dry... or so it is said. Few relics remain to prove such an age existed, and fewer still have an identifiable purpose. "Burning Earth" seems straightforward enough—it burns a victim with magical fire, and a cryptic rune seems to suggest that the power comes from the ground itself—but whoever constructed it remains a mystery. It shouldn't hurt a warrior's performance, aside from the nagging suspicion that the blade was not made for him... or any other humanoid.

SW1H61
Angurvadal +5
Burning Earth
There was a time before Neverwinter was warm and before the great Anauroch was dry... or so it is said. Few relics remain to prove such an age existed, and fewer still have an identifiable purpose. "Burning Earth" seems straightforward enough—it burns a victim with magical fire, and a cryptic rune seems to suggest that the power comes from the ground itself—but whoever constructed it remains a mystery. It looks a perfectly serviceable weapon, but something in the balance or grip is... wrong. It strains the forearm a touch, and does not fit the hand just right. It shouldn't hurt a warrior's performance, aside from the nagging suspicion that the blade was not made for him... or any other humanoid.

The true power of this burning sword has been unleashed by the Liquid Mercury.

STATISTICS:

Equipped abilities:
– Strength: +2

Combat abilities:
– Fiery: target suffers 1d8 fire damage
– Incendiary: target suffers 1 fire damage every round for 5 rounds
– Flame Whip: target is entangled in flames for 2 rounds (save vs. Breath at -2 negates)

THAC0: +5
Damage: 1d8+5 (slashing)
Speed Factor: 5
Proficiency Type: Long Sword
Type: One-handed
Requires:
 6 Strength

Weight: 4
Burning Earth
There was a time before Neverwinter was warm and before the great Anauroch was dry... or so it is said. Few relics remain to prove such an age existed, and fewer still have an identifiable purpose. "Burning Earth" seems straightforward enough—it burns a victim with magical fire, and a cryptic rune seems to suggest that the power comes from the ground itself—but whoever constructed it remains a mystery. It looks a perfectly serviceable weapon, but something in the balance or grip is... wrong. It strains the forearm a touch, and does not fit the hand just right. It shouldn't hurt a warrior's performance, aside from the nagging suspicion that the blade was not made for him... or any other humanoid.

The true power of this burning sword has been unleashed by the Liquid Mercury.

PARAMÈTRES : 

Capacités d'équipement : 
- Force : +2
- Camouflage dans l'ombre : -50 %
- Multiplicateur d'attaque sournoise : -1

Capacités de combat : 
- Inflige 1 points de dégâts de feu à la cible après 5 rounds
- Inflige 1 points de dégâts de feu à la cible après 4 rounds
- Inflige 1 points de dégâts de feu à la cible après 3 rounds
- Inflige 1 points de dégâts de feu à la cible après 2 rounds
- Inflige 1 points de dégâts de feu à la cible après 1 round
- Inflige 1d8 points de dégâts de feu à la cible
- Emprisonne la cible dans les flammes pendant 2 rounds (jet de sauvegarde contre les souffles pour éviter)

Enchantement : +5
TAC0 : +5
Dégâts : 1d8 +5
Type de dégâts : Tranchant
Facteur de vitesse : 5
Type de compétence : Épée longue
Type : Arme à 1 main

Poids : 4

Nécessite : 
- Force : 6
SW1H62
Foebane +4
The Archmage Demron crafted this magical bastard sword for the elven hero Fflar, Captain of Myth Drannor. The most powerful of six such enchanted blades Demron fashioned, Foebane can drain the very essence of life from its opponents with every blow, and bestow that life energy on the wielder. There are those who believe soul stealing capability has cursed the blade, for though fashioned as a weapon of right and justice, Foebane's dark history is one of murder and death.

Demron's own blood christened the blade, as a would be thief used the newly fashioned sword to bring about the Archmage's untimely death—though the thief did not survive the encounter, either. In the aftermath of Demron's murder, Foebane was recovered and presented to the hero Fflar to use in the defense of Myth Drannor, greatest of the elven cities.

Yet even the power of Foebane was not enough to withstand the dark hordes which overran Myth Drannor. When the elven city fell, Captain Fflar met a grisly, gruesome end and the sword itself was lost beneath the rubble of the once great metropolis.

Legend holds that Foebane's considerable powers are further augmented when the sword is reunited with the enchanted Scabbard of Fflar, its original owner.

NOTE: Foebane is always considered to be of +4 enchantment when determining what it can hit.

STATISTICS:

Equipped abilities:
– Saving Throws: +1

Combat abilities:
– Vampiric: target is drained 1d4 Hit Points and transfers them to the wielder
– Foe Bane: +3 to THAC0 and +5 to damage against undead, shapeshifters, and extraplanar beings

THAC0: +2
Damage: 1d10+2 (slashing)
Speed Factor: 7
Proficiency Type: Bastard Sword
Type: One-handed
Requires:
 11 Strength

Weight: 6
The Archmage Demron crafted this magical bastard sword for the elven hero Fflar, Captain of Myth Drannor. The most powerful of six such enchanted blades Demron fashioned, Foebane can drain the very essence of life from its opponents with every blow, and bestow that life energy on the wielder. There are those who believe soul stealing capability has cursed the blade, for though fashioned as a weapon of right and justice, Foebane's dark history is one of murder and death.

Demron's own blood christened the blade, as a would be thief used the newly fashioned sword to bring about the Archmage's untimely death—though the thief did not survive the encounter, either. In the aftermath of Demron's murder, Foebane was recovered and presented to the hero Fflar to use in the defense of Myth Drannor, greatest of the elven cities.

Yet even the power of Foebane was not enough to withstand the dark hordes which overran Myth Drannor. When the elven city fell, Captain Fflar met a grisly, gruesome end and the sword itself was lost beneath the rubble of the once great metropolis.

Legend holds that Foebane's considerable powers are further augmented when the sword is reunited with the enchanted Scabbard of Fflar, its original owner.

NOTE: Foebane is always considered to be of +4 enchantment when determining what it can hit.

PARAMÈTRES : 

Capacités d'équipement : 
- TAC0 : +3 contre les planétaires déchus

- TAC0 : +3 contre les devas déchues
- TAC0 : +3 contre les devas
- TAC0 : +3 contre les tieffelins
- TAC0 : +3 contre les githyankis
- TAC0 : +3 contre les génies
- TAC0 : +3 contre les élémentaires
- TAC0 : +3 contre les diablotins
- TAC0 : +3 contre les méphites
- TAC0 : +3 contre les rakshasas
- TAC0 : +3 contre les loups-garous
- TAC0 : +3 contre les démons
- TAC0 : +3 contre les dopplegangers
- TAC0 : +3 contre les morts-vivants
- TAC0 de la main secondaire : -1
- Jets de sauvegarde : +1
- Inflige 5 points de dégâts contre les planétaires déchus
- Inflige 5 points de dégâts contre les planétaires
- Inflige 5 points de dégâts contre les devas déchues

- Inflige 5 points de dégâts contre les démons

- Inflige 5 points de dégâts contre les morts-vivants
- Multiplicateur d'attaque sournoise : -2

Capacités de combat : 
- Draine 1d4 points de vie si la cible possède du sang et les transfère au porteur

SW1H63
Foebane +5
The Archmage Demron crafted this magical bastard sword for the elven hero Fflar, Captain of Myth Drannor. The most powerful of six such enchanted blades Demron fashioned, Foebane can drain the very essence of life from its opponents with every blow, and bestow that life energy on the wielder. There are those who believe soul stealing capability has cursed the blade, for though fashioned as a weapon of right and justice, Foebane's dark history is one of murder and death.

Demron's own blood christened the blade, as a would be thief used the newly fashioned sword to bring about the Archmage's untimely death—though the thief did not survive the encounter, either. In the aftermath of Demron's murder, Foebane was recovered and presented to the hero Fflar to use in the defense of Myth Drannor, greatest of the elven cities.

Yet even the power of Foebane was not enough to withstand the dark hordes which overran Myth Drannor. When the elven city fell, Captain Fflar met a grisly, gruesome end and the sword itself was lost beneath the rubble of the once great metropolis.

Reunited with Fflar's Holy Scabbard, Foebane is an even greater weapon than the legends claimed.

NOTE: Foebane is always considered to be of +5 enchantment when determining what it can hit.

STATISTICS:

Equipped abilities:
– Saving Throws: +2

Combat abilities:
– Vampiric: target is drained 1d4 Hit Points and transfers them to the wielder
– Holy: +5 to damage against evil creatures
– Foe Bane: +3 to THAC0 and +5 to damage against undead, shapeshifters, and extraplanar beings

THAC0: +3
Damage: 1d10+3 (slashing)
Speed Factor: 7
Proficiency Type: Bastard Sword
Type: One-handed
Requires:
 11 Strength

Weight: 6
The Archmage Demron crafted this magical bastard sword for the elven hero Fflar, Captain of Myth Drannor. The most powerful of six such enchanted blades Demron fashioned, Foebane can drain the very essence of life from its opponents with every blow, and bestow that life energy on the wielder. There are those who believe soul stealing capability has cursed the blade, for though fashioned as a weapon of right and justice, Foebane's dark history is one of murder and death.

Yet even the power of Foebane was not enough to withstand the dark hordes which overran Myth Drannor. When the elven city fell, Captain Fflar met a grisly, gruesome end and the sword itself was lost beneath the rubble of the once great metropolis.

Reunited with Fflar's Holy Scabbard, Foebane is an even greater weapon than the legends claimed.

SW1H64
Purifier +4
This single-handed weapon is infused with the very essence of virtue, and is rumored to be the sanctified blade of the famous paladin Sir Wediyer. The weapon was lost when Sir Wediyer pursued a fleeing pit fiend through a planar rift. Neither the fiend nor Sir Wediyer ever returned.

STATISTICS:

Equipped abilities:
– Magic Resistance: +5%

Combat abilities:
– Righteous: +3 to damage against evil creatures
– Cleansing: 15% chance evil creatures struck suffer various effects depending upon their level (save vs. Spell at -4 negates)

Target's Hit Dice - Effects of Cleansing
 More than 15 - Deafened for 1 turn
 15 or less - Blinded and Deafened for 1 turn
 10 or less - Paralyzed, Blinded, and Deafened for 1 turn
 5 or less - Killed

THAC0: +4
Damage: 1d10+4 (slashing)
Speed Factor: 7
Proficiency Type: Bastard Sword
Type: One-handed
Requires:
 11 Strength

Weight: 6
This single-handed weapon is infused with the very essence of virtue, and is rumored to be the sanctified blade of the famous paladin Sir Wediyer. The weapon was lost when Sir Wediyer pursued a fleeing pit fiend through a planar rift. Neither the fiend nor Sir Wediyer ever returned.

PARAMÈTRES : 

Capacités d'équipement : 
- TAC0 de la main secondaire : -1
- Inflige 3 points de dégâts contre les créatures mauvaises
- Multiplicateur d'attaque sournoise : -2
- Résistance à la magie : +5 %

Capacités de combat : 
- 15 % de chance d'aveugler les créatures mauvaises (de niveau 15 ou inférieur) pendant 1 round (jet de sauvegarde à -4 contre les sorts pour éviter)
- 15 % de chance d'étourdir les créatures mauvaises (de niveau 10 ou inférieur) pendant 1 tour (jet de sauvegarde à -4 contre les sorts pour éviter)
- 15 % de chance d'assourdir les créatures mauvaises pendant 1 tour (jet de sauvegarde à -4 contre les sorts pour éviter)
- 15 % de chance de tuer instantanément les créatures mauvaises (de niveau 5 ou inférieur) (jet de sauvegarde à -4 contre les sorts pour éviter)

Enchantement : +4
TAC0 : +4
Dégâts : 1d10 +4
Type de dégâts : Tranchant
Facteur de vitesse : 7
Type de compétence : Épée bâtarde
Type : Arme à 1 main

Poids : 6

Nécessite : 
- Force : 11
SW1H65
Purifier +5
This single-handed weapon is infused with the very essence of virtue, and is rumored to be the sanctified blade of the famous paladin Sir Wediyer. The weapon was lost when Sir Wediyer pursued a fleeing pit fiend through a planar rift. Neither the fiend nor Sir Wediyer ever returned.

With the Eye of Tyr set into its pommel, Purifier is perhaps the greatest single instrument of holy justice on the face of Faerûn.

STATISTICS:

Special abilities:
– Draw Upon Holy Might (once per day)
– Greater Restoration (once per day)

Equipped abilities:
– Magic Resistance: +15%

Combat abilities:
– Holy: +5 to damage against evil creatures
– Cleansing: 15% chance evil creatures struck suffer various effects depending upon their level (save vs. Spell at -4 negates)

Target's Hit Dice - Effects of Cleansing
 More than 20 - Deafened
 20 or less - Blinded and Deafened
 15 or less - Paralyzed, Blinded, and Deafened
 10 or less - Killed

THAC0: +5
Damage: 1d10+5 (slashing)
Speed Factor: 7
Proficiency Type: Bastard Sword
Type: One-handed
Requires:
 11 Strength

Weight: 6
This single-handed weapon is infused with the very essence of virtue, and is rumored to be the sanctified blade of the famous paladin Sir Wediyer. The weapon was lost when Sir Wediyer pursued a fleeing pit fiend through a planar rift. Neither the fiend nor Sir Wediyer ever returned.

With the Eye of Tyr set into its pommel, Purifier is perhaps the greatest single instrument of holy justice on the face of Faerûn.

Capacités d'équipement : 
- TAC0 de la main secondaire : -1
- Inflige 5 points de dégâts contre les créatures mauvaises
- Multiplicateur d'attaque sournoise : -2
- Résistance à la magie : +15 %

Capacités de charge : 
- Draw Upon Holy Might (1 fois par jour)
- Greater Restoration (1 fois par jour)

Capacités de combat : 
- 15 % de chance d'aveugler les créatures mauvaises (de niveau 20 ou inférieur) pendant 1 round (jet de sauvegarde à -4 contre les sorts pour éviter)
- 15 % de chance d'étourdir les créatures mauvaises (de niveau 15 ou inférieur) pendant 1 tour (jet de sauvegarde à -4 contre les sorts pour éviter)
- 15 % de chance d'assourdir les créatures mauvaises pendant 1 tour (jet de sauvegarde à -4 contre les sorts pour éviter)
- 15 % de chance de tuer instantanément les créatures mauvaises (de niveau 10 ou inférieur) (jet de sauvegarde à -4 contre les sorts pour éviter)

Usuno's Blade +3
The daughter of a high-ranking official within the bureaucratic society of Kara-Tur, Usuno rejected her family's station and carved a legend for herself among the Yakuza of the underworld. The blade of this enchanted ninjato crackles with electrical energy.

– Movement Rate: +1

SW1H68
Spectral Brand +4
When examined in direct sunlight, this mysterious scimitar becomes transparent and faint, almost disappearing from sight. As the lighting grows dimmer, however, the sword seems almost to gain substance from the darkness until it glows with a grey light in total darkness.

Legend has it that the souls of those who fall beneath this dark blade are forever enslaved, and can be summoned to fight at the side of the one who defeated them. Though this legendary power seems somehow sealed, Spectral Brand is still able to create an illusionary copy of itself capable of fighting alongside the wielder, and the chilling touch of its blade attacks directly the life force of any living creature.

STATISTICS:

Special abilities:
– Spectral Blade (once per day): the sword can attack on its own for 1 turn

Spectral Brand (10 HD):
 HP 48, AC 0, THAC0 4, APR 2
 1d8+8 Magic (Spectral Brand +4)
 Saving Throws 9/13/9/11/13, AL TN
 SR 100%, CR 100%, PR 100%, MR 100%
 FR 100%, CR 100%, ER 100%, AR 100%

Special Characteristics:
– Protected Against: Backstabs and Poison
– Mind Shield: conferred protection against many forms of mind-affecting magic, such as charm, command, confusion, emotion, domination, fear, feeblemind, hold, sleep, stun, psionics, and other similar effects

Combat abilities:
– Icy: target suffers 1d6 cold damage
– Spectral Blade: +3 to THAC0

THAC0: +4
Damage: 1d8+4 (slashing)
Speed Factor: 5
Proficiency Type: Scimitar
Type: One-handed
Requires:
 8 Strength

Weight: 4
When examined in direct sunlight, this mysterious scimitar becomes transparent and faint, almost disappearing from sight. As the lighting grows dimmer, however, the sword seems almost to gain substance from the darkness until it glows with a grey light in total darkness.

Legend has it that the souls of those who fall beneath this dark blade are forever enslaved, and can be summoned to fight at the side of the one who defeated them. Though this legendary power seems somehow sealed, Spectral Brand is still able to create an illusionary copy of itself capable of fighting alongside the wielder, and the chilling touch of its blade attacks directly the life force of any living creature.

PARAMÈTRES :

- Multiplicateur d'attaque sournoise : -1

Capacités de charge : 
- Spectral Blade (1 fois par jour)

Capacités de combat : 
- Inflige 1d6 points de dégâts de froid à la cible

Type de dégâts : Tranchant
Facteur de vitesse : 5
Type de compétence : Scimitar
Type : Arme à 1 main

- Force : 8
SW1H68A
Spectral Brand +4


Capacités d'équipement : 
- Multiplicateur d'attaque sournoise : -2
- Résistance aux poisons : +100 %
- Le moral du porteur reste au plus haut

- Immunité au sommeil
- Immunité à la confusion
- Immunité aux attaques sournoises

Type : Arme à 1 main

SW1H69
Spectral Brand +5
When examined in direct sunlight, this mysterious scimitar becomes transparent and faint, almost disappearing from sight. As the lighting grows dimmer, however, the sword seems almost to gain substance from the darkness until it glows with a grey light in total darkness.

Legend has it that the souls of those who fall beneath this dark blade are forever enslaved, and can be summoned to fight at the side of the one who defeated them. Though this legendary power seems somehow sealed, Spectral Brand is still able to create an illusionary copy of itself capable of fighting alongside the wielder, and the chilling touch of its blade attacks directly the life force of any living creature.

Drawing upon the necromancy of the Skull of the Lich the seal has been broken, and Spectral Brand is now an instrument of unholy death that should never have been unleashed upon the Realms.

STATISTICS:

Special abilities:
– Spectral Blade (once per day): the sword can attack on its own for 1 turn
– Dark Swarm (once per day): releases enslaved souls in the form of shadows, summoning one every round for 1 turn

Spectral Brand (12 HD):
 HP 54, AC 0, THAC0 1, APR 3
 1d8+10 Magic (Spectral Brand +5)
 Saving Throws 8/12/8/10/12, AL TN
 SR 100%, CR 100%, PR 100%, MR 100%
 FR 100%, CR 100%, ER 100%, AR 100%

Special Characteristics:
– Protected Against: Backstabs and Poison
– Mind Shield: conferred protection against many forms of mind-affecting magic, such as charm, command, confusion, emotion, domination, fear, feeblemind, hold, sleep, stun, psionics, and other similar effects

Equipped abilities:
– Spell: Negative Plane Protection

Combat abilities:
– Icy: target suffers 1d8 cold damage
– Spectral Blade: +3 to THAC0

THAC0: +5
Damage: 1d8+5 (slashing)
Speed Factor: 5
Proficiency Type: Scimitar
Type: One-handed
Requires:
 8 Strength

Weight: 4
When examined in direct sunlight, this mysterious scimitar becomes transparent and faint, almost disappearing from sight. As the lighting grows dimmer, however, the sword seems almost to gain substance from the darkness until it glows with a grey light in total darkness.

Legend has it that the souls of those who fall beneath this dark blade are forever enslaved, and can be summoned to fight at the side of the one who defeated them. Though this legendary power seems somehow sealed, Spectral Brand is still able to create an illusionary copy of itself capable of fighting alongside the wielder, and the chilling touch of its blade attacks directly the life force of any living creature.

Drawing upon the necromancy of the Skull of the Lich the seal has been broken, and Spectral Brand is now an instrument of unholy death that should never have been unleashed upon the Realms.

SW1H70
Hindo's Doom +4
Hindo was a ronin of great renown, a staunch defender of his people against the evil overlords who killed his master and ravaged his homelands.

"... in the night there came the rain of fire, which crashed as though an avalanche of stone. There were craters in the square, and inside were the stars, from which we forged our vengeance and took back the land of our fathers." The writings of Kaa Mihnd, explaining how a poor fishing village could possess the weapon to challenge their wealthy overlord. The account has never been verified, though this blade is the supposed outcome, as well as Hindo's deeds which have passed into legend.

STATISTICS:

Special abilities:
– Lesser Restoration (once per day)

Equipped abilities:
– Magic Resistance: +5%

Combat abilities:
– Tenchu: 5% chance of casting Holy Smite upon the target

THAC0: +4
Damage: 1d10+4 (slashing)
Speed Factor: 5
Proficiency Type: Katana / Wakizashi
Type: One-handed
Requires:
 6 Strength

Weight: 5

There were craters in the square, and inside were the stars, from which we forged our vengeance and took back the land of our fathers." The writings of Kaa Mihnd, explaining how a poor fishing village could possess the weapon to challenge their wealthy overlord. The account has never been verified, though this blade is the supposed outcome, as well as Hindo's deeds which have passed into legend.

SW1H71
Hindo's Doom +5
Hindo was a ronin of great renown, a staunch defender of his people against the evil overlords who killed his master and ravaged his homelands.

"... in the night there came the rain of fire, which crashed as though an avalanche of stone. There were craters in the square, and inside were the stars, from which we forged our vengeance and took back the land of our fathers." The writings of Kaa Mihnd, explaining how a poor fishing village could possess the weapon to challenge their wealthy overlord. The account has never been verified, though this blade is the supposed outcome, as well as Hindo's deeds which have passed into legend.

Reunited with the hand of its original owner, Hindo's Doom is a katana worthy of the greatest of samurai.

STATISTICS:

Special abilities:
– Greater Restoration (once per day)

Equipped abilities:
– Magic Resistance: +10%
– Spell: Death Ward

Combat abilities:
– Tenchu: 15% chance of casting Holy Smite upon the target

Speed Factor: 5
Proficiency Type: Katana / Wakizashi
Type: One-handed
Requires:
 6 Strength

Weight: 5

There were craters in the square, and inside were the stars, from which we forged our vengeance and took back the land of our fathers." The writings of Kaa Mihnd, explaining how a poor fishing village could possess the weapon to challenge their wealthy overlord. The account has never been verified, though this blade is the supposed outcome, as well as Hindo's deeds which have passed into legend.

Reunited with the hand of its original owner, Hindo's Doom is a katana worthy of the greatest of samurai.

SW1H72
Bastard Sword +3
Also known as the hand-and-a-half sword, the bastard sword derives its name from the fact that it is halfway between the two-handed sword and the long sword. The bastard sword has a double-edged blade and a long grip, which can accommodate both hands if preferred. The overall length of the bastard sword ranges between four feet and four feet ten inches. This is a magical bastard sword.

STATISTICS:

THAC0: +3
Damage: 1d10+3 (slashing)
Speed Factor: 7
Proficiency Type: Bastard Sword
Type: One-handed
Requires:
 11 Strength

Weight: 6

This is a magical bastard sword.

SW1H75
Katana +3
It is no simple deed to enchant a katana. Unlike conventional weapons, the katana is already a near-perfect fighting sword. Improving it further usually requires a sacrifice; perhaps a dying samurai might beg a Wu Jen to infuse his fighting spirit into his sword. The wielder of an enchanted katana such as this one must respect the customs of Kara-Tur and of the samurai who once carried the blade into battle. Not doing so could drastically change one's luck for the worse.

STATISTICS:

THAC0: +3
Damage: 1d10+3 (slashing)
Speed Factor: 5
Proficiency Type: Katana / Wakizashi
Type: One-handed
Requires:
 6 Strength

Weight: 5
It is no simple deed to enchant a katana. Unlike conventional weapons, the katana is already a near-perfect fighting sword. Improving it further usually requires a sacrifice; perhaps a dying samurai might beg a Wu Jen to infuse his fighting spirit into his sword. The wielder of an enchanted katana such as this one must respect the customs of Kara-Tur and of the samurai who once carried the blade into battle. Not doing so could drastically change one's luck for the worse.

SW1H76
Scimitar +3
The long, curved, single-edged blade is characteristic of both the sabre and the scimitar, even though their origins lie in different parts of Faerûn. Whereas the sabre was intended mainly for horsemen due to its versatility, the scimitar has a heavier oriental influence. The "shamshir," as it was originally called, is larger, has a greater curve to it, and is tapered to an elongated, sharp point. Thus, it is slightly slower, but tends to be more effective and deadly in combat. This particular weapon has been enhanced magically to augment the skill of the wielder.

STATISTICS:

THAC0: +3
Damage: 1d8+3 (slashing)
Speed Factor: 5
Proficiency Type: Scimitar
Type: One-handed
Requires:
 8 Strength

Weight: 4
The long, curved, single-edged blade is characteristic of both the sabre and the scimitar, even though their origins lie in different parts of Faerûn. Whereas the sabre was intended mainly for horsemen due to its versatility, the scimitar has a heavier oriental influence. The "shamshir," as it was originally called, is larger, has a greater curve to it, and is tapered to an elongated, sharp point. Thus, it is slightly slower, but tends to be more effective and deadly in combat. This particular weapon has been enhanced magically to augment the skill of the wielder.

SW1H77
The Answerer +4
The last swing of a battle is more important than the first. Such is the philosophy embodied in this powerful weapon. Although the strange design of The Answerer makes it difficult to take the initiative in combat, with each hit it makes an opponent more vulnerable to subsequent attacks.

STATISTICS:

Equipped abilities:
– Answerer: when struck by an opponent, the wielder gains one extra attack in the next round

Combat abilities:
– Pierce Magic: target suffers -5% to magic resistance for 5 rounds
– Sundering: target suffers cumulative -1 to Armor Class for 2 rounds

THAC0: +4
Damage: 1d8+4 (slashing)
Speed Factor: 1
Proficiency Type: Long Sword
Type: One-handed
Requires:
 6 Strength

Weight: 4

SW1H79
The Harrower +1
This double-edged long sword gleams white even in the reddest of torchlight. The Dethek runes along its sides name the blade "Harrower," a weapon once wielded by Ariabel, a Waterdhavian Paladin of Lathander who carried the weapon into combat against the vampire Zerafex and her host of unholy spawn. Ariabel did not survive the contest, but decades later a gang of Tethyrian tomb robbers recovered her sword from the crypt where she fell.

STATISTICS:

Combat abilities:
– Undead Bane: +3 to THAC0 and +5 to damage against undead
– The Harrower: +2 to enchantment level against undead

SW2H01
Two-handed Sword
The two-handed sword is a derivative of the long sword. Weaponsmiths have always looked for ways to improve existing weapons, and in an effort to improve the long sword, the blade was lengthened. Eventually, the handle had to be extended and two hands became necessary to properly swing the sword. The primary function of two-handed swords is cleaving mounted knights and breaking up pike formations.

STATISTICS:

Damage: 2d6 (slashing)
Speed Factor: 10
Proficiency Type: Two-handed Sword
Type: Two-handed
Requires:
 14 Strength

Weight: 8
The two-handed sword is a derivative of the long sword. Weaponsmiths have always looked for ways to improve existing weapons, and in an effort to improve the long sword, the blade was lengthened. Eventually, the handle had to be extended and two hands became necessary to properly swing the sword. The primary function of two-handed swords is cleaving mounted knights and breaking up pike formations.

- Multiplicateur d'attaque sournoise : -3

Dégâts : 2d6 
Type de dégâts : Tranchant
Facteur de vitesse : 10
Type de compétence : Épée à deux mains
Type : Arme à 2 mains

SW2H02
Two-handed Sword +1
The two-handed sword is a derivative of the long sword. Weaponsmiths have always looked for ways to improve existing weapons, and in an effort to improve the long sword, the blade was lengthened. Eventually, the handle had to be extended and two hands became necessary to properly swing the sword. The primary function of two-handed swords is cleaving mounted knights and breaking up pike formations. This sword is particularly good at its job, as it has been enchanted with a few magical properties.

STATISTICS:

THAC0: +1
Damage: 2d6+1 (slashing)
Speed Factor: 10
Proficiency Type: Two-handed Sword
Type: Two-handed
Requires:
 14 Strength

Weight: 8

The primary function of two-handed swords is cleaving mounted knights and breaking up pike formations. This sword is particularly good at its job, as it has been enchanted with a few magical properties.

SW2H03
Berserking Sword +3
This is a cursed sword which performs perfectly under every test, save in the heat of battle. Upon entering combat, the wielder will immediately go berserk, killing everything within reach until either calming down or falling unconscious. A very powerful sword, but one must decide whether or not it is worth the risk. Even after the battle fury has ended, this sword can only be removed via magical means.

STATISTICS:

*CURSED*

Equipped abilities:
– Berserking: the wielder goes berserk and totally out of control when in combat

Combat abilities:
– Speed: 1 extra attack per round

THAC0: +3
Damage: 2d6+3 (slashing)
Speed Factor: 10
Proficiency Type: Two-handed Sword
Type: Two-handed
Requires:
 14 Strength

Weight: 8
This is a cursed sword which performs perfectly under every test, save in the heat of battle. Upon entering combat, the wielder will immediately go berserk, killing everything within reach until either calming down or falling unconscious. A very powerful sword, but one must decide whether or not it is worth the risk. Even after the battle fury has ended, this sword can only be removed via magical means.

Capacités d'équipement : 
- Maudit : Ne peut être ôté qu'à l'aide d'un sort de Délivrance de la malédiction
- Attaque par round : +1
- Multiplicateur d'attaque sournoise : -3
- Provoque la folie du berserker chez le porteur

SW2H06
Spider's Bane +2
Spider's Bane was originally forged by the dwarves of the Orothiar tribe in Cloakwood. They created the blade to help foster good will between them and the Grand Dukes of Baldur's Gate. Wielded by the Grand Dukes for about a century, the sword was eventually lost in a fight against ettercaps and spiders. The present whereabouts of the blade are unknown, but its recovery would aid greatly in fighting the current spider infestation that plagues the Cloakwood.

STATISTICS:

Equipped abilities:
– Protects Against: Poison and Web

Damage: 2d6+2 (slashing)
Speed Factor: 10
Proficiency Type: Two-handed Sword
Type: Two-handed
Requires:

Weight: 8

SW2H07
Harbinger +3
When the hero Trueblood destroyed the Harbinger, a demon gorging itself on the blood of peasant folk near Luskan, he bound its essence in the only vessel capable of holding it, his fabled sword, Deliverance. Though the evil creature was dominated by the will of the semi-sentient blade, it was not truly defeated, and it transformed the weapon from within. Now it acts much like any other enchanted weapon, but when it strikes, there is a chance that a burst of flames erupts, a sign that the demon within still rages at its imprisonment.

NOTE: Harbinger is always considered to be of +3 enchantment when determining what it can hit.

STATISTICS:

Equipped abilities:
– Hellfire: 5% chance wielder suffers 3d6 fire damage (save vs. Spell negates)

Combat abilities:
– Starmetal: +5 to damage against extraplanar creatures
– Demon Bane: +3 to THAC0 and +5 to damage against demons
– Banishing: summoned and gated creatures are dismissed (save vs. Spell at -2 negates)

THAC0: +1
Damage: 2d6+1 (slashing)
Speed Factor: 10
Proficiency Type: Two-handed Sword
Type: Two-handed
Requires:
 14 Strength

Weight: 8
When the hero Trueblood destroyed the Harbinger, a demon gorging itself on the blood of peasant folk near Luskan, he bound its essence in the only vessel capable of holding it, his fabled sword, Deliverance. Though the evil creature was dominated by the will of the semi-sentient blade, it was not truly defeated, and it transformed the weapon from within. Now it acts much like any other enchanted weapon, but when it strikes, there is a chance that a burst of flames erupts, a sign that the demon within still rages at its imprisonment.

NOTE: Harbinger is always considered to be of +3 enchantment when determining what it can hit.

Capacités d'équipement : 
- TAC0 : +3 contre les démons
- Inflige 5 points de dégâts contre les planétaires déchus
- Inflige 5 points de dégâts contre les planétaires
- Inflige 5 points de dégâts contre les devas déchues
- Inflige 5 points de dégâts contre les devas
- Inflige 5 points de dégâts contre les tieffelins
- Inflige 5 points de dégâts contre les githyankis
- Inflige 5 points de dégâts contre les génies
- Inflige 5 points de dégâts contre les élémentaires
- Inflige 5 points de dégâts contre les diablotins
- Inflige 5 points de dégâts contre les méphites
- Inflige 5 points de dégâts contre les rakshasas
- Inflige 5 points de dégâts contre les démons
- Multiplicateur d'attaque sournoise : -3

Capacités de combat : 
- 5 % de chance d'infliger 3d6 points de dégâts de feu au porteur (jet de sauvegarde contre les sorts pour éviter)

SW2H08
Soul Reaver +4
Thirsting for fresh blood, usually only a warrior intent on death and destruction wields such an evil blade. Some warriors claiming to be doing good have attempted to master the Soul Reaver and use it for noble purposes, but more often than not, they are found surrounded by carnage and death too horrible to bear. One such warrior was found in a cathedral, surrounded by the corpses of priests and resting on the end of his own blade, where he had thrown himself in a fit of guilt.

STATISTICS:

Combat abilities:
– Powerful Weapon: +2 to damage
– Enervating: living creatures struck suffer 1d6 magic damage and are drained 1 level (save vs. Death neg. level loss)

THAC0: +4
Damage: 2d6+4 (slashing)
Speed Factor: 10
Proficiency Type: Two-handed Sword
Type: Two-handed
Requires:
 16 Strength

Weight: 10

SW2H09
Warblade +3
This massive two-handed sword is an enchanted version of the barbaric swords of the Northern tribes. Forged during battle and dipped in the blood of the brave fallen, the enchantment granted to the blade by the barbarian gods is incredible. This huge 52" long blade needs much effort to be properly handled, thus only the strongest warriors can hope to wield such a powerful tool of destruction.

STATISTICS:

Combat abilities:
– Crushing: target suffers 1d6 crushing damage
– Oversized: +4 to damage, -2 to THAC0

THAC0: +3
Damage: 2d6+3 (slashing)
Speed Factor: 10
Proficiency Type: Two-handed Sword
Type: Two-handed
Requires:
 18 Strength

Weight: 12

SW2H10
Carsomyr +4
The Holy Avenger
Carsomyr is a weapon of legend, perhaps one of the most powerful blades ever forged on Faerûn, though its origin and history is thought purposefully forgotten, so that the sword itself will never overshadow the importance of the struggles that must be fought today. It is infused with the very essence of virtue, and requires as much from any paladin that would hope to wield it. The evils of the Realms must truly stand aside when this weapon is brought to bear, for their magic is dispelled with a word, and steadfastly resisted with ease. Carsomyr also harbors a special distaste for the forces of evil and chaos, and such creatures must fear additional damage from its touch in battle.

STATISTICS:

Special abilities:
– Dispel Magic (three times per day)

Equipped abilities:
– Magic Resistance: +10%

Combat abilities:
– Powerful Weapon: +2 to damage
– Righteous: +3 to damage against evil creatures
– Dispelling: removes all magical effects from the target (save vs. Spell negates)

THAC0: +4
Damage: 2d6+4 (slashing)
Speed Factor: 10
Proficiency Type: Two-handed Sword
Type: Two-handed
Requires:
 16 Strength

Weight: 10
The Holy Avenger
Carsomyr is a weapon of legend, perhaps one of the most powerful blades ever forged on Faerûn, though its origin and history is thought purposefully forgotten, so that the sword itself will never overshadow the importance of the struggles that must be fought today. It is infused with the very essence of virtue, and requires as much from any paladin that would hope to wield it. The evils of the Realms must truly stand aside when this weapon is brought to bear, for their magic is dispelled with a word, and steadfastly resisted with ease. Carsomyr also harbors a special distaste for the forces of evil and chaos, and such creatures must fear additional damage from its touch in battle.

- Inflige 3 points de dégâts contre les créatures mauvaises
- Multiplicateur d'attaque sournoise : -3
- Résistance à la magie : +10 %

Capacités de charge : 
- Remove Magic (3 fois par jour)

Capacités de combat : 
- Dissipation de la magie (jet de sauvegarde contre les sorts pour éviter)

Enchantement : +4
TAC0 : +4
Dégâts : 2d6 +6
Type de dégâts : Tranchant

SW2H11
Two-handed Sword +2
The two-handed sword is a derivative of the long sword. Weaponsmiths have always looked for ways to improve existing weapons, and in an effort to improve the long sword, the blade was lengthened. Eventually, the handle had to be extended and two hands became necessary to properly swing the sword. The primary function of two-handed swords is cleaving mounted knights and breaking up pike formations. This particular sword is even more capable of such functions, serving as a fearful reminder of what comes of the union between weaponsmithing and sorcery.

STATISTICS:

THAC0: +2
Damage: 2d6+2 (slashing)
Speed Factor: 10
Proficiency Type: Two-handed Sword
Type: Two-handed
Requires:
 14 Strength

Weight: 8
The two-handed sword is a derivative of the long sword. Weaponsmiths have always looked for ways to improve existing weapons, and in an effort to improve the long sword, the blade was lengthened. Eventually, the handle had to be extended and two hands became necessary to properly swing the sword. The primary function of two-handed swords is cleaving mounted knights and breaking up pike formations. This particular sword is even more capable of such functions, serving as a fearful reminder of what comes of the union between weaponsmithing and sorcery.

SW2H12
Flame of the North +2
The title does not refer to the blade itself, though appropriate, but rather to the woman who originally wielded it in the icy hinterlands of Faerûn. Her name was Carerra, and she was a veritable firestorm that swept across arctic trolls and the northern orcish tribes. She was a hated enemy of many a shaman whose magic often floundered against her berserker's fury. After a lifetime of raucous battle, it was old age that eventually claimed her. The sword was passed to her granddaughter, an adventurer, who presumably brought it to Amn.

STATISTICS:

Combat Abilities
– Icy: target suffers 1d4 cold damage
– Freezing: 33% chance target is held for 1 round (save vs. Polymorph negates)

THAC0: +2
Damage: 2d6+2 (slashing)
Speed Factor: 10
Proficiency Type: Two-handed Sword
Type: Two-handed
Requires:
 14 Strength

Weight: 8

SW2H14
Lilarcor +3
Lawrence Lilarcor was well known, not for being brave, but as an idiot. As the tale goes, the boastful Lilarcor left his village at the urging of his friends so that the "great hero" could do battle with a devious Treant. He walked for days in the dead of winter until, feverish, he found his target and began an epic wrestling match. Unfortunately (or perhaps luckily), the "Treant" was nothing more than a craggy old normal oak. His friends had been jesting, not actually expecting that Lilarcor would go fight the fictitiously dangerous tree. That might have been the end of it, but Lilarcor, not really knowing what a Treant was in the first, didn't realize the truth. He eventually uprooted the oak and, marching proudly home, he declared himself a hero. Thus was born a laughing stock of epic proportions, and over time the name of Lilarcor became the sacrificial fool in many tales of "less than brilliance."

It is not known whether this enchanted weapon is Lilarcor himself, perhaps imprisoned by an evil mage or some other odd coincidence of fate, but it certainly acts in a manner consistent with his level of competence. If it is he, he has never bemoaned his captivity. He might not realize, or care, that he is no longer a human.

As a weapon, Lilarcor has its uses, but many a warrior has eventually given it away. Banter such as, "Ouch, that musta hurt," "Oh yeah! Got 'im good," and "Beware my bite for it might... might... might really hurt or something," is a constant barrage on a warrior's psyche.

STATISTICS:

Equipped abilities:
– Protects Against: Charm, Confusion, and Domination

THAC0: +3
Damage: 2d6+3 (slashing)
Speed Factor: 10
Proficiency Type: Two-handed Sword
Type: Two-handed
Requires:
 14 Strength

Weight: 8
Lawrence Lilarcor was well known, not for being brave, but as an idiot. As the tale goes, the boastful Lilarcor left his village at the urging of his friends so that the "great hero" could do battle with a devious Treant. He walked for days in the dead of winter until, feverish, he found his target and began an epic wrestling match. Unfortunately (or perhaps luckily), the "Treant" was nothing more than a craggy old normal oak. His friends had been jesting, not actually expecting that Lilarcor would go fight the fictitiously dangerous tree. That might have been the end of it, but Lilarcor, not really knowing what a Treant was in the first, didn't realize the truth. He eventually uprooted the oak and, marching proudly home, he declared himself a hero. Thus was born a laughing stock of epic proportions, and over time the name of Lilarcor became the sacrificial fool in many tales of "less than brilliance."

It is not known whether this enchanted weapon is Lilarcor himself, perhaps imprisoned by an evil mage or some other odd coincidence of fate, but it certainly acts in a manner consistent with his level of competence. If it is he, he has never bemoaned his captivity. He might not realize, or care, that he is no longer a human.

As a weapon, Lilarcor has its uses, but many a warrior has eventually given it away. Banter such as, "Ouch, that musta hurt," "Oh yeah! Got 'im good," and "Beware my bite for it might... might... might really hurt or something," is a constant barrage on a warrior's psyche.

PARAMÈTRES :

- Multiplicateur d'attaque sournoise : -3
- Immunité à la confusion
- Immunité aux charmes

Enchantement : +3
TAC0 : +3
Dégâts : 2d6 +3
Type de dégâts : Tranchant
Facteur de vitesse : 10
Type de compétence : Épée à deux mains
Type : Arme à 2 mains

Poids : 8

Nécessite : 
- Force : 14
SW2H15
Silver Sword +4
This vorpal Silver Sword radiates a dark aura when you examine it, and the blade is so finely sharpened, it could likely sever a head in a single blow. These swords are highly sought after, and a cult of githyanki knights called the "Sword Stalkers" is tasked with recovering any swords that fall into the hands of the unworthy, i.e. non githyanki.

STATISTICS:

Combat abilities:
– Very Keen: +10% chance to score critical hits
– Vorpal: 15% chance target dies (save vs. Death at -2 for 3d8 slashing damage)

THAC0: +4
Damage: 2d6+4 (slashing)
Speed Factor: 10
Proficiency Type: Two-handed Sword
Type: Two-handed
Requires:
 14 Strength

Weight: 8

SW2H16
Sword of Chaos +2
The blade of Sarevok, brother of , used in the battle they fought in faraway Baldur's Gate.  prevailed, destroying Sarevok's plans and rescuing the Sword Coast from the brink of war. The sword itself defies identification, likely forged specifically for Sarevok to best focus the infernal energy he hoped to control. Much of its power died with him.

SW2H17
Gram the Sword of Grief +4
Some weapons are evil from their inception, imbued with corrupting magics by cruel mages. But there are also weapons that owe their natures not to any particular enchantment, but to dastardly acts performed in the hands of their wielders. Gram, once a legendary sword of the great hero Siegfried, is now forever stained with the blood of countless innocents. The blade is particularly sharp and well-balanced, and in a certain light one can see the faint image of a serpent within the hilt.

STATISTICS:

Equipped abilities:
– Physical Resistance: +5%

Combat abilities:
– Armor Piercing: +3 to THAC0
– Wounding: target suffers 1 bleeding damage every round for 5 rounds

THAC0: +4
Damage: 2d6+4 (slashing)
Speed Factor: 10
Proficiency Type: Two-handed Sword
Type: Two-handed
Requires:
 14 Strength

Weight: 8
Some weapons are evil from their inception, imbued with corrupting magics by cruel mages. But there are also weapons that owe their natures not to any particular enchantment, but to dastardly acts performed in the hands of their wielders. Gram, once a legendary sword of the great hero Siegfried, is now forever stained with the blood of countless innocents. The blade is particularly sharp and well-balanced, and in a certain light one can see the faint image of a serpent within the hilt.

- Inflige 1 point de dégâts de poison à chaque round pendant 5 rounds

SW2H18
Gram the Sword of Grief +5
Some weapons are evil from their inception, imbued with corrupting magics by cruel mages. But there are also weapons that owe their natures not to any particular enchantment, but to dastardly acts performed in the hands of their wielders. Gram, once a legendary sword of the great hero Siegfried, is now forever stained with the blood of countless innocents. The blade is particularly sharp and well-balanced, and in a certain light one can see the faint image of a serpent within the hilt.

Siegfried's fearsome blade is even more powerful with the Heart of the Damned set into its pommel.

STATISTICS:

Equipped abilities:
– Physical Resistance: +10%

Combat abilities:
– Armor Piercing: +3 to THAC0
– Wounding: target suffers 1 bleeding damage every round for 5 rounds
– Grevious Poison: 15% chance of dealing 5d6 poison damage

THAC0: +5
Damage: 2d6+5 (slashing)
Speed Factor: 10
Proficiency Type: Two-handed Sword
Type: Two-handed
Requires:
 14 Strength

Weight: 8
Some weapons are evil from their inception, imbued with corrupting magics by cruel mages. But there are also weapons that owe their natures not to any particular enchantment, but to dastardly acts performed in the hands of their wielders. Gram, once a legendary sword of the great hero Siegfried, is now forever stained with the blood of countless innocents. The blade is particularly sharp and well-balanced, and in a certain light one can see the faint image of a serpent within the hilt.

Siegfried's fearsome blade is even more powerful with the Heart of the Damned set into its pommel.

PARAMÈTRES : 

Capacités d'équipement : 
- Multiplicateur d'attaque sournoise : -3
- Résistance aux dégâts physiques : +10 %

Capacités de combat : 
- Inflige 1 point de dégâts de poison à chaque round pendant 5 rounds
- 15 % de chance d'infliger 5d6 points de dégâts de poison à la cible

Enchantement : +5
TAC0 : +8
Dégâts : 2d6 +5
Type de dégâts : Tranchant
Facteur de vitesse : 10
Type de compétence : Épée à deux mains
Type : Arme à 2 mains

Poids : 8

Nécessite : 
- Force : 14
SW2H19
Carsomyr +5
The Holy Avenger
Carsomyr is a weapon of legend, perhaps one of the most powerful blades ever forged on Faerûn, though its origin and history is thought purposefully forgotten, so that the sword itself will never overshadow the importance of the struggles that must be fought today. It is infused with the very essence of virtue, and requires as much from any paladin that would hope to wield it. The evils of the Realms must truly stand aside when this weapon is brought to bear, for their magic is dispelled with a word, and steadfastly resisted with ease. Carsomyr also harbors a special distaste for the forces of evil and chaos, and such creatures must fear additional damage from its touch in battle.

Even a holy relic as powerful as Carsomyr is made even greater when combined with the Eye of Tyr.

STATISTICS:

Special abilities:
– Dispel Magic (three times per day)

Equipped abilities:
– Magic Resistance: +20%

Combat abilities:
– Powerful Weapon: +2 to damage
– Holy: +5 to damage against evil creatures
– Dispelling: removes all magical effects from the target (save vs. Spell negates)

THAC0: +5
Damage: 2d6+5 (slashing)
Speed Factor: 10
Proficiency Type: Two-handed Sword
Type: Two-handed
Requires:
 16 Strength

Weight: 10
The Holy Avenger
Carsomyr is a weapon of legend, perhaps one of the most powerful blades ever forged on Faerûn, though its origin and history is thought purposefully forgotten, so that the sword itself will never overshadow the importance of the struggles that must be fought today. It is infused with the very essence of virtue, and requires as much from any paladin that would hope to wield it. The evils of the Realms must truly stand aside when this weapon is brought to bear, for their magic is dispelled with a word, and steadfastly resisted with ease. Carsomyr also harbors a special distaste for the forces of evil and chaos, and such creatures must fear additional damage from its touch in battle.

Even a holy relic as powerful as Carsomyr is made even greater when combined with the Eye of Tyr.

- Résistance à la magie : +20 %

SW2H20
Two-handed Sword +3
The two-handed sword is a derivative of the long sword. Weaponsmiths have always looked for ways to improve existing weapons, and in an effort to improve the long sword, the blade was lengthened. Eventually, the handle had to be extended and two hands became necessary to properly swing the sword. The primary function of two-handed swords is cleaving mounted knights and breaking up pike formations. This particular sword is even more capable of such functions, serving as a fearful reminder of what comes of the union between weaponsmithing and sorcery.

STATISTICS:

THAC0: +3
Damage: 2d6+3 (slashing)
Speed Factor: 10
Proficiency Type: Two-handed Sword
Type: Two-handed
Requires:
 14 Strength

Weight: 8

The primary function of two-handed swords is cleaving mounted knights and breaking up pike formations. SW2H21
Psion's Blade +3
Some believe this massive blade to be of drow origin, though others dispute this claim. However, all agree this great sword was fashioned with a single purpose... to rid the world of the Illithid. A threat Mind Flayers don't take kindly.

The illithid brain known as Kwukgixrin sent its followers to scouring the underdark for this blade that it discovered when it absorbed the mind of a powerful human warrior. After countless fights the warrior had hidden the sword when he realized that he was too wounded to survive another attack from the illithid thralls. Before the illithid thralls could find the sword, the warrior's twin brother discovered it. The twin was in strong health and he made short work of the thralls and many illithids before leaving the Underdark.

STATISTICS:

Equipped abilities:
– Mind Barrier: +2 to Armor Class and Saving Throws vs. psionics

Combat abilities:
– Mindbreaking: 15% chance target is feebleminded (save vs. Spell at -4 negates)

THAC0: +3
Damage: 2d6+3 (slashing)
Speed Factor: 10
Proficiency Type: Two-handed Sword
Type: Two-handed
Requires:
 14 Strength

Weight: 8

SW2H22
The Gold Digger +1
Crafted by dwarves in service to the temple of Waukeen in Amn, this two-handed sword draws power from the gold in its wielder's purse. For the wealthy, it deals mighty blows—for the impoverished, the Gold Digger is no better than a mundane greatsword.
